TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}
TEXT.source: ti ḍail kati gagang (Kułałau village, p.224)

S.TRANSL: There were a monkey and a crab.

S.FORM: "ari, kiitjui," aya; sa vaik a maḍusa.
"ari, kiitjoi," aya; sa vaik a madrosa.
S.TRANSL: “Come on, let’s collect loquat fruit,” they said; and the two of them went off.
They got to the tree,
and the crab was going to try to climb up.
But he couldn’t; he just slipped down.

S.FORM: saka ti ḍaiḍail anga a łevavaw.
saka ti draidrail anga a ljevavaw.
S.TRANSL: So it was the monkey who climbed up.

S.FORM: manu nu izuanga kiniitju ni ḍaiḍail, gesgesen a kaikapu, sa katjani a namalum, sa łułu-i ni gagang.
mano no izoanga kiniitjo ni draidrail, gesgesen a kaikapo, sa katjani a namalom, sa ljoljo-i ni gagang.
S.TRANSL: When the monkey had picked any loquats, the crab shook the cloth container, and ripe ones fell out, and the crab picked them up.

S.FORM: "aku a keḍi anga ku kiniitju, qalian? lingu su getselen a ku kaikapu."
"ako a kedri anga ko kiniitjo, qalian? lingo so gecelen a ko kaikapo."
S.TRANSL: “Friend, why are there so few left of what I’ve picked? Perhaps you have torn the cloth.”

S.FORM: "anema naya, qalian? qayamu a su kaikapu, tu ki zua verits kemuda."
"anema naya, qalian? qayamo a so kaikapo, to ki zoa veric kemoda."
S.TRANSL: “What are you saying, friend? Look at your cloth, to see whether there is a tear or anything.”
When he looked, there was no tear.

S.FORM: "pai, qalian, ku łinułu sakamaya," aya ti gagang.
"pai, qalian, ko ljinoljo sakamaya," aya ti gagang.
S.TRANSL: “Well, friend, I just picked them up,” said the crab.
“Let’s go home.”
Next day they went to get miscanthus grass for torches.
“Well, friend, let’s try burning one another.”

S.FORM: "tiaken-ay anan tjaisangas," sa łamain ni ḍaiḍail.
"tiaken-ay anan tjaisangas," sa ljamain ni draidrail.
S.TRANSL: “Well I’ll go first,” (said the crab), and the monkey set fire (to the grass).
“What do you think of my fire, friend?”
“It’s nothing to a tough male like me.
I’m still here.

S.FORM: sa tisun-ay anan, qalian i ḍaiḍail."
sa tison-ay anan, qalian i draidrail."
S.TRANSL: Now it’s your turn, friend monkey.”

S.FORM: łevavaw ta kasiw ti ḍaiḍail; łamain ni gagang.
ljevavaw ta kasiw ti draidrail; ljamain ni gagang.
S.TRANSL: The monkey went up a tree, and the crab set fire to it (or the grass).
“What do you think of my fire, friend?”
“It’s nothing to a tough male like me.
I’m still here.”
Then the fire went out.
The monkey couldn’t be heard any more.

S.FORM: "ku kimaw anan ti ku qali," aya.
"ko kimaw anan ti ko qali," aya.
S.TRANSL: “I’ll go and look for my friend,” said the crab.
He found him, and he was dead.

S.FORM: "ki ku kuda-i sa ti ku qali, sa mevałut?"
"ki ko koda-i sa ti ko qali, sa mevaljot?"
S.TRANSL: “What am I to do to bring my friend back to life?”

S.FORM: sa vutsiqi, sa sualapi a qavuvung, sa tsapa-i.
sa vociqi, sa soalapi a qavovong, sa capa-i.
S.TRANSL: He cut him open, took out his heart, and dried it.
“How will my friend come back to life?” he said.
Then he came back to life.

S.FORM: "uzai, qalian, a ku kiniḍalułan tua se Tjuvałułukay," ayain.
"ozai, qalian, a ko kinidraloljan toa se Tjovaljoljokay," ayain.
S.TRANSL: “Here, friend, is what I won off the Tjuvałułukay people,” he said;
and they ate it. And they said: “Come on, let’s go home.”
It got dark.
“Come on, friend, let’s go courting.”

S.FORM: sa "ika ken a uri kisudju, qalian," aya ti gagang.
sa "ika ken a ori kisodjo, qalian," aya ti gagang.
S.TRANSL: “I’m not going courting, friend,” said the crab.

S.FORM: manu kitjavilił ti gagang, sa paka patekuteku tua garałigał.
mano kitjavililj ti gagang, sa paka patekoteko toa garaljigalj.
S.TRANSL: But the crab followed, and went along underneath the bed-space.

S.FORM: manu getselen a qalitsi ni ḍaiḍail, sa vaikan.
mano gecelen a qalici ni draidrail, sa vaikan.
S.TRANSL: He pinched off the monkey’s penis, and went off with it.

S.FORM: manu vaik a sema vangaw ti gagang.
mano vaik a sema vangaw ti gagang.
S.TRANSL: The crab went up to the sky-light.

S.FORM: sipałeteku tua kinsa ni Tjukutjuku ti ḍaiḍail; kemakan anga ti ḍaiḍail.
sipaljeteko toa kinsa ni Tjokotjoko ti draidrail; kemakan anga ti draidrail.
S.TRANSL: Tjukutjuku set some food before the monkey, and the monkey was eating it.

S.FORM: tjanian a paka vangaw tua qalitsi pasa tua kinsa.
tjanian a paka vangaw toa qalici pasa toa kinsa.
S.TRANSL: Through the sky-light was the way the crab dropped the penis into the food.

S.FORM: "iyaa, niaken a qalitsi tsu," aya ti ḍaiḍail, sa sułułu-i, sa vaikan a tjumaq.
"iyaa, niaken a qalici co," aya ti draidrail, sa soljoljo-i, sa vaikan a tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: “Ugh! This is my penis,” said the monkey, and picked it out, and took it home.

S.FORM: "aku azua su sualapen a ku qalitsi?"
"ako azoa so soalapen a ko qalici?"
S.TRANSL: “Why did you remove my penis?”

S.FORM: "nataqed aken sakamaya," aya ti gagang a kitevela.
"nataqed aken sakamaya," aya ti gagang a kitevela.
S.TRANSL: “I was asleep all the time,” said the crab to excuse himself.
That’s the end of the story.
